Award.AwardTitle: The transport of dissolved organic matter by river networks from mountains to the sea: a re-examination of the role of flow across temporal and spatial scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will facilitate the collaboration of a group of scientists interested in delivery, transport and transformation of organic matter in a variety of surface waters. The group will synthesize data across spatial and temporal scales and bring together a multi-disciplinary team at the John Wesley Powell Center for Analysis and Synthesis. The effort will re-evaluate the fundamental relationships between discharge and DOM concentration and composition and focus on synthesizing mature datasets from small headwater basins to large coastal basins using statistical techniques and modeling. Data are available that represent a range of temporal sampling intensities from seasonal samples, to more frequent samples from automated samplers, and finally to data from continuous optical sensors.

This synthesis collaboration is expected to advance scientific understanding of the processes and patterns of organic matter transport by exploring key data sets at a level of detail and scale that has not previously been attempted. The work is expected to also benefit the policy and management communities that rely on data, models, and understanding of the controls on nutrient, trace metal, and pollutant transport in river networks and to estuaries. This is a joint synthesis projects with the USGS Powell Center, Fort Collins Colorado.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a synthesis of how dissolved organic matter, which is mostly composed of dissolved organic carbon, is transported from land to the sea. Understanding this process is important because it is a major part of global carbon cycling and also impacts water quality in river basins. The project entailed two meetings in 2012 and 2013 where experts in aquatic dissolved organic matter (DOM) synthesized our current understanding of DOM behavior in river basins and large data sets were synthesized.
    The conceptual synthesis highlighted how much more stable DOM variability is than previously understood. Water DOM concentrations vary little between headwaters and large rivers, even though they are such different environments. Also, the temporal variability of DOM concentrations is low. This spatial and temporal stability of DOM is not well understood, thus we have posed new challenges to the scientific community for new measurements and studies that can help address this knowledge gap.
    Data analysis showed the temporal variability of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) concentrations in major rivers, like the Colorado and Missouri Rivers. Climate variability, particularly temperature and precipitation patterns, is a major control on the temporal variation of DOC, however, this control can be heavily dampened by large reservoirs.
    The formation of this synthesis group also built new connections between researchers in the field of DOM chemistry and transport in natural waters. Those connections created new opportunities to advance our understanding of how DOM will respond to global environmental change.
